Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The UCLA Mentoring Underrepresented Scholars in Engineering (MUSE) project addresses a National Science Board critical need of increasing engineering and computing degrees for the technical workforce and strengthening America's global competiveness. The project design derives from seminal research in active learning communities and its application to low-income engineering students from underrepresented groups. The project provides the resources to recruit, retain, mentor and graduate low-income underrepresented freshmen, community college transfers, and continuing students in the Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science. For each year of the grant, MUSE scholarships are awarded to 5 incoming freshmen, 5 new community college transfer students, and 10 continuing students. Key project objectives are for the MUSE Scholars to succeed in gatekeeper courses and to exceed the School's overall retention to graduation percentage. To achieve these outcomes, MUSE provides support structures to increase Scholar's persistence and performance in gatekeeper engineering and computing courses. Additionally, the project provides closely monitored faculty and industry mentoring programs and professional development for Scholars to enter the workforce or advanced study. The MUSE project is adding to the understanding of retention in engineering by both broadening the participation and increasing graduation percentage of-low income engineering students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM 2012-2017 project titled Mentoring Underrepresented Students in Engineering (MUSE) supported sixty-eight (68) low-income, first generation and underrepresented engineering students (URES). Of this number, 29 freshmen, 17 transfers, and 22 third-year students were recognized as NSF S-STEM Scholars at the Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity (CEED) Scholarship Banquets over the five year period. Twenty-two (22) scholars have graduated so far and fourty-three of MUSE Scholars are persisting in good standing. Nationally only 40% of the URES freshmen cohorts ever graduate with a BS degree.1,2 In comparison, the UCLA S-STEM project achieved a retenion to gradation of of 96%.

 

Essentially, the URES attrition problem results from the fact that high-performing, multi-risk students are educated in low-performing urban and rural high schools and are raised in challenged neighborhoods. These talented students succumb to the intensity of the 1st and 2nd year university math/science courses.3 However, research show that these background characteristics are not solely responsible for such high attrition; rather, the university environment contributes to this. There are three critical transition points that lead to high attrition among URES groups—(I) Freshmen transitioning from high school, (II) Rising third-year URES entering the engineering ‘gatekeeper’ courses that often contribute to student attrition, and (III) Incoming community college (CC) students who transfer into engineering and computer science are shocked by rigor workload. These transitions can and do impede academic and social integration as well as reduce student involvement, vigilance, and self-confidence that undermine a “sense of belonging” in the engineering milieu. CEED’s academic and social integration approach addresses the retention challenge amongst this population by forming successive URES cohorts into a peer-supportive community pursuing academic mastery, engagement, and persistence towards degree completion.

 

The MUSE project incorporated previous S-STEM and STEP curricular and co-curricular interventions and active/cooperative learning methods into the critical transition model. The MUSE project introduced two co-curricular activities: 1) Triad Mentoring Program directed at improving Scholars’ self-efficacy and academic performance, and 2) Career Planning and Leadership Seminar. The MUSE triad mentoring program provides Scholars with three mentor schemes: I) Scholars were required to meet twice a quarter with their major field faculty mentor, double the requirement for all engineering students; II) Scholars participated in ‘deep dive’ mentoring experiences with CEED Industry Advisory Board members; and III) Scholars were supported by ‘fun’ peer group mentoring events organized by engineering student organizations.

 

Thus far, at MUSE project end, twenty-two scholars graduated from the School of Engineering and Applied Science (the School), 64% (14/22) graduated with a GPA above 3.0; six graduated with a GPA above 2.7; and 2 graduated with a GPA above 2.5. Five of the twenty-two scholars have been admitted and will attend graduate school. Of the 43 remaining S-STEM scholars in the School at the end date, 19 have filed to graduate in June 2017, and 58% (11/19) of those have committed to graduate school for Fall 2018. The number of S-STEM MUSE scholars who will attend graduate school is 16/41 scholars (40%) of those who have graduated thus far.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project proposed a range of quality interventions and activities aimed to investigate URES integration into the academic and social engineering culture. The MUSE objective was to close the academic and social gaps that all URES bring from high school. The mentoring program was focused solely on the MUSE Scholars. The summer bridge component made a strong impact on first quarter grades and created a close-knit peer supportive community. Analyzing the academic and non-academic curricular and co-curricular activities of the MUSE project should reveal association between interventions and Scholars’ performance and attitudes. Future work may more directly link particular MUSE activities with the positive outcomes achieved. Greater understanding may be had by teasing out which experiences, events, and activities students themselves link to their individual and collective group successes.

 

Broader Impact: The large majority of the low-income and first-generation students admitted to the School graduated from low-performing urban and rural high schools. They constitute the high-performing, multi-risk student population in bottom 40% of all School admits. Hence, they are the prime S-STEM scholarship and MUSE target. The MUSE project was designed as a high-impact practice, the intervention program is based upon the theories of Tinto (integration into the university academic and social systems), Bean (attitudes and behaviors drive academics), and Astin (degree and quality of involvement predicts success) to increase persistence in engineering and computer science.

 

[1]American Society for Engineering Education. (2012). Going the Distance: Best practices and strategies for retaining engineering, engineering technology, and computing students

[2] Executive Office of the President. 2012. Report to the President. Engage to Excel: producing one million additional college graduates with degrees in STEM. PCAST.

[3]Chen, X. 2014. STEM Attrition among high-performing college students: Scope and potential causes. Journal of Technology and Science Education. 5(1):41-59.

Of this number, 29 freshmen, 17 transfers, and 22 third-year students were recognized as NSF S-STEM Scholars at the Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity (CEED) Scholarship Banquets over the five year period. Twenty-two (22) scholars have graduated so far and fourty-three of MUSE Scholars are persisting in good standing. There are three critical transition points that lead to high attrition among URES groups—(I) Freshmen transitioning from high school, (II) Rising third-year URES entering the engineering ?gatekeeper? courses that often contribute to student attrition, and (III) Incoming community college (CC) students who transfer into engineering and computer science are shocked by rigor workload. These transitions can and do impede academic and social integration as well as reduce student involvement, vigilance, and self-confidence that undermine a "sense of belonging" in the engineering milieu. CEED?s academic and social integration approach addresses the retention challenge amongst this population by forming successive URES cohorts into a peer-supportive community pursuing academic mastery, engagement, and persistence towards degree completion. The MUSE project incorporated previous S-STEM and STEP curricular and co-curricular interventions and active/cooperative learning methods into the critical transition model. The MUSE project introduced two co-curricular activities: 1) Triad Mentoring Program directed at improving Scholars? self-efficacy and academic performance, and 2) Career Planning and Leadership Seminar. The MUSE triad mentoring program provides Scholars with three mentor schemes: I) Scholars were required to meet twice a quarter with their major field faculty mentor, double the requirement for all engineering students; II) Scholars participated in ?deep dive? mentoring experiences with CEED Industry Advisory Board members; and III) Scholars were supported by ?fun? peer group mentoring events organized by engineering student organizations. Thus far, at MUSE project end, twenty-two scholars graduated from the School of Engineering and Applied Science (the School), 64% (14/22) graduated with a GPA above 3.0; six graduated with a GPA above 2.7; and 2 graduated with a GPA above 2.5. Five of the twenty-two scholars have been admitted and will attend graduate school. The number of S-STEM MUSE scholars who will attend graduate school is 16/41 scholars (40%) of those who have graduated thus far. The MUSE objective was to close the academic and social gaps that all URES bring from high school. The mentoring program was focused solely on the MUSE Scholars. The summer bridge component made a strong impact on first quarter grades and created a close-knit peer supportive community. Analyzing the academic and non-academic curricular and co-curricular activities of the MUSE project should reveal association between interventions and Scholars? performance and attitudes. Future work may more directly link particular MUSE activities with the positive outcomes achieved. Greater understanding may be had by teasing out which experiences, events, and activities students themselves link to their individual and collective group successes. Broader Impact: The large majority of the low-income and first-generation students admitted to the School graduated from low-performing urban and rural high schools. They constitute the high-performing, multi-risk student population in bottom 40% of all School admits. Hence, they are the prime S-STEM scholarship and MUSE target.
